question: On the Day of Atonement, what did the high priest do with the scapegoat?
explanation: The scapegoat carried the people's sins into the wilderness, symbolizing their removal.

verses.kjv: And the goat shall bear upon him all their iniquities unto a land not inhabited: and he shall let go the goat in the wilderness.

question: What were Israelites commanded to do every seventh year?
explanation: Every seventh year was a Sabbath for the land, when fields were not to be sown or reaped.

verses.kjv: But in the seventh year shall be a sabbath of rest unto the land, a sabbath for the LORD: thou shalt neither sow thy field, nor prune thy vineyard.

question: What festival celebrates the giving of the Law at Mount Sinai?
explanation: Pentecost, occurring 50 days after Passover, commemorates when God gave the Law at Sinai.

verses.kjv:
In the third month, when the children of Israel were gone forth out of the land of Egypt, the same day came they
into the wilderness of Sinai.

question: What was the Year of Jubilee?
choices: Every 50th year when slaves were freed and land returned
The year the king was crowned
explanation: The 50th year was the Year of Jubilee when liberty was proclaimed, slaves freed, and property returned.

verses.kjv:
And ye shall hallow the fiftieth year, and proclaim liberty throughout
all the land unto all the inhabitants thereof: it shall be a jubile unto you; and ye shall return every man unto his possession, and ye shall return every man unto his family.

question: What was the Feast of Trumpets?
choices: A day of rest and sacred assembly
explanation: The first day of the seventh month was to be a day of sabbath rest, commemorated with trumpet blasts.

verses.kjv:
Speak unto the children of Israel, saying, In the seventh month, in the first
day of the month, shall ye have a sabbath, a memorial of blowing of trumpets, an holy convocation.

question: What does the Hebrew word 'Selah' in Psalms likely mean?
explanation: Selah appears throughout the Psalms and is thought to indicate a pause for reflection or a musical interlude.

verses.kjv:
Many
there be which say of my soul,
There is no help for him in God. Selah.

question: What did the high priest wear on his breastplate?
explanation: Mount four rows of precious stones on the breastplate, representing the twelve tribes of Israel.

verses.kjv:
And thou shalt set in it settings of stones,
even four rows of stones:
the first row
shall be a sardius, a topaz, and a carbuncle:
this shall be the first row.
And the second row
shall be an emerald, a sapphire, and a diamond.
And the third row a ligure, an agate, and an amethyst.
And the fourth row a beryl, and an onyx, and a jasper: they shall be set in gold in their inclosings.
And the stones shall be with the names of the children of Israel, twelve, according to their names,
like the engravings of a signet; every one with his name shall they be according to the twelve tribes.

question: What was the purpose of the Year of Jubilee?
choices: To free slaves and return property
explanation: Consecrate the fiftieth year and proclaim liberty throughout the land to all its inhabitants.

verses.kjv:
And ye shall hallow the fiftieth year, and proclaim liberty throughout
all the land unto all the inhabitants thereof: it shall be a jubile unto you; and ye shall return every man unto his possession, and ye shall return every man unto his family.

question: What was the scapegoat in the Day of Atonement ceremony?
choices: A goat sent into the wilderness bearing sins
explanation: The goat chosen by lot as the scapegoat shall be sent into the wilderness to take away the sins of the people.

verses.kjv:
But the goat, on which the lot fell to be the scapegoat, shall be presented alive before the LORD, to make an atonement with him,
and
 to let him go for a scapegoat into the wilderness.

question: What did Jews wear to remind them of God's commandments?
explanation: Make tassels on the corners of your garments to help you remember all the commands of the Lord.

verses.kjv:
Speak unto the children of Israel, and bid them that they make them fringes in the borders of their garments throughout their generations, and that they put upon the fringe of the borders a ribband of blue:
And it shall be unto you for a fringe, that ye may look upon it, and remember all the commandments of the LORD, and do them; and that ye seek not after your own heart and your own eyes, after which ye use to go a whoring:

question: What is the Feast of Tabernacles also called?
explanation: Say to the Israelites: 'On the fifteenth day of the seventh month the Lord's Festival of Tabernacles begins.'

verses.kjv:
Speak unto the children of Israel, saying, The fifteenth day of this seventh month
shall be the feast of tabernacles
for seven days unto the LORD.

question: What is Pentecost also called?
explanation: Count off seven weeks from the day after the Sabbath until the Feast of Weeks.

verses.kjv: And ye shall count unto you from the morrow after the sabbath, from the day that ye brought the sheaf of the wave offering; seven sabbaths shall be complete:

question: How often was the Year of Jubilee celebrated?
explanation: Consecrate the fiftieth year and proclaim liberty throughout the land.

verses.kjv:
And ye shall hallow the fiftieth year, and proclaim liberty throughout
all the land unto all the inhabitants thereof: it shall be a jubile unto you; and ye shall return every man unto his possession, and ye shall return every man unto his family.

question: What did Jews write on their doorposts?
explanation: Write them on the doorframes of your houses and on your gates.

verses.kjv: And thou shalt write them upon the posts of thy house, and on thy gates.

question: What was the Sabbath day journey limit?
explanation: Then the apostles returned to Jerusalem from the Mount of Olives, a Sabbath day's walk from the city.

verses.kjv: Then returned they unto Jerusalem from the mount called Olivet, which is from Jerusalem a sabbath day’s journey.

question: What were Jews required to do every seventh year regarding debts?
explanation: At the end of every seven years you must cancel debts.

verses.kjv:
At the end of
every seven years thou shalt make a release.
And this
is the manner of the release: Every creditor that lendeth
ought unto his neighbour shall release
it; he shall not exact
it of his neighbour, or of his brother; because it is called the LORD’S release.

question: What were Jews commanded to wear on the corners of their garments?
explanation: Speak to the Israelites and say to them: 'Make tassels on the corners of your garments.'

verses.kjv: Speak unto the children of Israel, and bid them that they make them fringes in the borders of their garments throughout their generations, and that they put upon the fringe of the borders a ribband of blue:

question: What were Israelite men required to appear before the Lord with three times a year?
explanation: Three times a year all the men are to appear before the Sovereign Lord.

verses.kjv: Three times in the year all thy males shall appear before the Lord GOD.

question: What month was Passover celebrated?
explanation: This month is to be for you the first month, the first month of your year.

verses.kjv:
This month
shall be unto you the beginning of months: it
shall be the first month of the year to you.

question: On what day of the month was Passover celebrated?
explanation: Take care of them until the fourteenth day of the month, when all the members of the community of Israel must slaughter them at twilight.

verses.kjv: And ye shall keep it up until the fourteenth day of the same month: and the whole assembly of the congregation of Israel shall kill it in the evening.

question: How were the Israelites to eat the Passover meal?
choices: With cloak tucked in, sandals on, and staff in hand
explanation: This is how you are to eat it: with your cloak tucked into your belt, your sandals on your feet and your staff in your hand. Eat it in haste; it is the Lord's Passover.

question: What animal did the high priest sacrifice on the Day of Atonement?
explanation: Aaron shall bring the bull for his own sin offering to make atonement for himself and his household, and he is to slaughter the bull for his own sin offering.

verses.kjv:
And Aaron shall bring the bullock of the sin offering, which
is
 for himself, and shall make an atonement for himself, and for his house, and shall kill the bullock of the sin offering which
is for himself:

question: On the Day of Atonement, the live goat was sent away into the wilderness "for" whom?
explanation: Leviticus 16:10 says the goat was presented alive before the LORD and sent away into the wilderness for Azazel.

verses.kjv:
But the goat, on which the lot fell to be the scapegoat, shall be presented alive before the LORD, to make an atonement with him,
and
 to let him go for a scapegoat into the wilderness.

question: In Exodus, which animal's firstling was commanded to be redeemed with a lamb?
explanation: Exodus 13:13 says every firstling of a donkey was to be redeemed with a lamb (or its neck broken if not redeemed).

verses.kjv: And every firstling of an ass thou shalt redeem with a lamb; and if thou wilt not redeem it, then thou shalt break his neck: and all the firstborn of man among thy children shalt thou redeem.

question: According to Exodus, what were the Israelites commanded to keep as a memorial between their eyes?
choices: A memorial of the law of the LORD
A stone from the Red sea
explanation: Exodus 13:9 says it shall be for a sign upon thine hand and for a memorial between thine eyes, that the LORD's law may be in thy mouth.

verses.kjv: And it shall be for a sign unto thee upon thine hand, and for a memorial between thine eyes, that the LORD's law may be in thy mouth: for with a strong hand hath the LORD brought thee out of Egypt.

question: What did the LORD command the priests to blow over the burnt offerings and the sacrifices of peace offerings?
explanation: Numbers 10:10 commands blowing the trumpets over burnt offerings and peace offerings as a memorial before God.

verses.kjv: Also in the day of your gladness, and in your solemn days, and in the beginnings of your months, ye shall blow with the trumpets over your burnt offerings, and over the sacrifices of your peace offerings; that they may be to you for a memorial before your God: I am the LORD your God.

question: What did the LORD call the offering of the firstfruits after Pentecost in Leviticus 23?
choices: A new meat offering unto the LORD
explanation: Leviticus 23:16 says on the fiftieth day they were to offer a new meat offering unto the LORD.

verses.kjv: Even unto the morrow after the seventh sabbath shall ye number fifty days; and ye shall offer a new meat offering unto the LORD.

question: What were the Israelites commanded not to do in their harvest until they brought an offering to their God?
choices: Eat bread, or parched corn, or green ears
explanation: Leviticus 23:14 forbids eating these harvest foods until the offering is brought.

verses.kjv: And ye shall eat neither bread, nor parched corn, nor green ears, until the selfsame day that ye have brought an offering unto your God: it shall be a statute for ever throughout your generations in all your dwellings.

question: When a man vowed a vow to the LORD or swore an oath, what did Numbers say he must not do to his word?
choices: He shall not break his word
He shall write his word on stone
explanation: Numbers 30:2 commands that he must not break his word, but do according to all that proceeds from his mouth.

verses.kjv: If a man vow a vow unto the LORD, or swear an oath to bind his soul with a bond; he shall not break his word, he shall do according to all that proceedeth out of his mouth.

question: What did the LORD command the children of Israel to wear on the borders of their garments throughout their generations?
explanation: Numbers 15:38 commands them to make fringes on the borders of their garments.

verses.kjv: Speak unto the children of Israel, and bid them that they make them fringes in the borders of their garments throughout their generations, and that they put upon the fringe of the borders a ribband of blue:

question: What color ribband were the Israelites commanded to put upon the fringe of the borders of their garments?
explanation: Numbers 15:38 says they were to put upon the fringe of the borders a ribband of blue.

verses.kjv: Speak unto the children of Israel, and bid them that they make them fringes in the borders of their garments throughout their generations, and that they put upon the fringe of the borders a ribband of blue:

question: What were the Israelites commanded to do to the corners of their fields when they reaped the harvest?
explanation: Leviticus 19:9 commands not wholly reaping the corners, and not gathering the gleanings.

verses.kjv: And when ye reap the harvest of your land, thou shalt not wholly reap the corners of thy field, neither shalt thou gather the gleanings of thy harvest.

question: What were the Israelites commanded not to do with the gleanings of their vineyard?
explanation: Leviticus 19:10 says they must not gather the gleanings of their vineyard nor every grape, leaving them for the poor and stranger.

verses.kjv: And thou shalt not glean thy vineyard, neither shalt thou gather every grape of thy vineyard; thou shalt leave them for the poor and stranger: I am the LORD your God.

question: What were the Israelites commanded not to do on the sabbath besides no work in Leviticus 23:3?
explanation: Leviticus 23:3 states the sabbath is a holy convocation and they shall do no work therein.

verses.kjv: Six days shall work be done: but the seventh day is the sabbath of rest, an holy convocation; ye shall do no work therein: it is the sabbath of the LORD in all your dwellings.

question: What were the Israelites commanded to do with the person who ate with blood (as stated in Leviticus 19:26)?
choices: Not eat any thing with the blood
Bring two doves to the priest
explanation: Leviticus 19:26 commands, "Ye shall not eat any thing with the blood."

verses.kjv: Ye shall not eat any thing with the blood: neither shall ye use enchantment, nor observe times.

question: What did the LORD say must not be left until the morning from the sacrifice of the feast of the passover in Exodus 34?
choices: The sacrifice of the feast of the passover
The lamb's blood on the doorposts
explanation: Exodus 34:25 says the sacrifice of the feast of the passover shall not be left unto the morning.

verses.kjv: Thou shalt not offer the blood of my sacrifice with leaven; neither shall the sacrifice of the feast of the passover be left unto the morning.

question: What did God command Israel to do with the firstfruits of their land?
choices: Bring them to the house of the LORD thy God
Store them in their own barns
explanation: Exodus 34:26 commands bringing the first of the firstfruits to the house of the LORD.

verses.kjv: The first of the firstfruits of thy land thou shalt bring unto the house of the LORD thy God. Thou shalt not seethe a kid in his mother's milk.

question: What did the LORD command not to be done with a kid in Exodus 34:26?
choices: Seethe a kid in his mother's milk
Offer a kid for a burnt offering
Eat a kid on the sabbath
Bring a kid to the priest
explanation: Exodus 34:26 ends with the command, "Thou shalt not seethe a kid in his mother's milk."

verses.kjv: The first of the firstfruits of thy land thou shalt bring unto the house of the LORD thy God. Thou shalt not seethe a kid in his mother's milk.

question: In Esther, what were the days of Purim not to fail from among the Jews?
explanation: Esther 9:28 says these days should be remembered and kept, and should not fail from among the Jews throughout every generation.

verses.kjv: And that these days should be remembered and kept throughout every generation, every family, every province, and every city; and that these days of Purim should not fail from among the Jews, nor the memorial of them perish from their seed.

question: According to Esther, what did the Jews make the days of Purim into for themselves and their seed?
explanation: Esther 9:27 says the Jews ordained and took upon them and their seed, "so as it should not fail," to keep it according to the writing and the time appointed every year.

verses.kjv: The Jews ordained, and took upon them, and upon their seed, and upon all such as joined themselves unto them, so as it should not fail, that they would keep these two days according to their writing, and according to their appointed time every year;

question: At the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem in Nehemiah, what two groups were appointed for giving thanks?
choices: Two great companies of them that gave thanks
Two companies of priests with trumpets only
Two groups of singers and no priests
Two bands of soldiers marching silently
explanation: Nehemiah 12:31 says he brought the princes upon the wall and appointed two great companies of them that gave thanks.

verses.kjv: Then I brought up the princes of Judah upon the wall, and appointed two great companies of them that gave thanks, whereof one went on the right hand upon the wall toward the dung gate:

question: In Nehemiah, what did the people do on the twenty and fourth day of the month as they assembled?
choices: Fast, with sackclothes, and earth upon them
Offer a burnt offering of bulls
Build booths and dwell in them
explanation: Nehemiah 9:1 says they assembled with fasting, sackclothes, and earth upon them.

verses.kjv: Now in the twenty and fourth day of this month the children of Israel were assembled with fasting, and with sackclothes, and earth upon them.

question: What did the people do for a fourth part of the day when they stood in their place in Nehemiah 9:3?
choices: Read in the book of the law of the LORD their God
explanation: Nehemiah 9:3 states they read in the book of the law for a fourth part of the day.

verses.kjv: And they stood up in their place, and read in the book of the law of the LORD their God one fourth part of the day; and another fourth part they confessed, and worshipped the LORD their God.

question: What did the people do for another fourth part of the day in Nehemiah 9:3?
choices: Confessed, and worshipped the LORD their God
explanation: Nehemiah 9:3 says another fourth part they confessed and worshipped the LORD their God.

verses.kjv: And they stood up in their place, and read in the book of the law of the LORD their God one fourth part of the day; and another fourth part they confessed, and worshipped the LORD their God.

question: At the dedication of the wall, what did they offer with gladness in Nehemiah 12:43?
explanation: Nehemiah 12:43 says they offered great sacrifices that day and rejoiced with great joy.

verses.kjv: Also that day they offered great sacrifices, and rejoiced: for God had made them rejoice with great joy: the wives also and the children rejoiced: so that the joy of Jerusalem was heard even afar off.

question: In Amos, what did God say He would not accept even if Israel offered certain offerings?
explanation: Amos 5:22 says God would not accept their burnt offerings and meat offerings, nor regard the peace offerings of their fat beasts.

verses.kjv: Though ye offer me burnt offerings and your meat offerings, I will not accept them: neither will I regard the peace offerings of your fat beasts.

question: In Isaiah, what yearly custom does the prophet mention regarding the king and the people?
choices: A custom in a solemn feast
explanation: Isaiah 16:10 mentions "as was their custom in solemn feasts" in describing the noise of harvest joy ceasing.

verses.kjv: And gladness is taken away, and joy out of the plentiful field; and in the vineyards there shall be no singing, neither shall there be shouting: the treaders shall tread out no wine in their presses; I have made their vintage shouting to cease.

question: What did God command Israel to do on the fifteenth day of the seventh month regarding offerings (as described in Numbers 29:12)?
choices: Keep a solemn feast and do no servile work
Build an altar of unhewn stone only
explanation: Numbers 29:12 commands keeping a solemn feast unto the LORD, doing no servile work, and offering offerings made by fire seven days.

verses.kjv: And on the fifteenth day of the seventh month ye shall have an holy convocation; ye shall do no servile work, and ye shall keep a feast unto the LORD seven days:

question: When Israel offered a peace offering, what did the priest do with the blood?
choices: Sprinkle it round about upon the altar
Pour it into a golden cup and keep it
Carry it outside the camp and bury it
explanation: Leviticus 3:2 states that the priests sprinkled the blood of the peace offering round about upon the altar.

verses.kjv: And he shall lay his hand upon the head of his offering, and kill it at the door of the tabernacle of the congregation: and Aaron's sons the priests shall sprinkle the blood upon the altar round about.

question: What were the Israelites commanded to do with the blood of the burnt offering?
choices: Sprinkle it round about upon the altar that is by the door of the tabernacle
Put it on the horns of the golden altar
Mix it with oil and pour it on the ground
Carry it into the holy place and pour it out there
explanation: Leviticus 1:5 says the priests were to bring the blood and sprinkle it round about upon the altar by the door of the tabernacle.

verses.kjv: And he shall kill the bullock before the LORD: and the priests, Aaron's sons, shall bring the blood, and sprinkle the blood round about upon the altar that is by the door of the tabernacle of the congregation.
